intro: Amelanchier parviflora subsp. parviflora, commonly known as the common serviceberry, is a deciduous shrub or small tree native to eastern North America. It typically grows to a height of 3–10 meters and features opposite, ovate leaves that turn yellow in autumn. The plant produces clusters of white or pink flowers in early spring, followed by edible, dark blue berries in the summer. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodlands or along stream banks. Its ornamental value and ecological importance make it a popular choice for landscaping and wildlife habitat.
